programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Where We Call Home
programme.sub-title: Keeping the Fires of Tradition Burning
programme.desc: We meet two Americans who preserve Japanese traditions. Chris Hinds ensures the safe conduct of Nozawa Onsen's fire festival in Nagano Prefecture, and Andrew Mancabelli crafts Japanese armor in Warabi, Saitama Prefecture.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.sub-title: Aiming for Glory : Japan's Senior Esports Team
programme.desc: In northern Japan, a senior esports team with an average age of 69 is aiming high. Pushed relentlessly by their coach, more than 30 years their junior, they dream of competing in a world championship.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.sub-title: Veggies Patiently Pickled for the Cold Season
programme.desc: Hi! It's me, Tama. In winter, I never stray far away from my warm friend, Mr. Stove. But Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are off to see our neighbor to learn how to make pickles. Not me. I'm staying right here. The only thing I need to know about pickles is how to eat them!

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Activate Your Japanese!
programme.desc: Drama "Xuan Tackles Japan!" Three days before the summer festival, Xuan is at the shrine grounds preparing the stage with Danny, Monica, Aoi and other locals. After Tadokoro leaves them with convoluted instructions, everyone is confused about how the chairs and tables should be arranged. Xuan tries to find Tadokoro, but Yansu reminds her that she should be able to explain. Xuan comes round to the idea of explaining the layout to everyone herself. But the information is complicated. How can she explain it in an easy-to-understand manner? "Onomatopoeia" -Share Feelings- Texture of Food 1 "Welcome to My Japan!" focuses on the life of Romain LEBRUN from Belgium, who works as a salt master at a salt farm in Ishikawa Prefecture!

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.desc: 'Bosai Leaders' promote mutual resident support before and during disasters, and these days foreign participants are playing a significant role. We introduce those being trained in Nakano Ward, Tokyo.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.desc: We introduce a lineup of programs conveying Japan's unique perspectives and cultural practices. Themes include falconry, etiquette, and the National Museum of Japanese History.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: New Life for the Samurai Genre
programme.desc: Yasuda Junichi directed "A Samurai in Time," a playful film made on a shoestring budget that became a word-of-mouth hit. Yasuda, who is also a rice farmer, gives us the behind-the-scenes story.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: The most common winning technique in sumo is when a rikishi forces their opponent out of the ring using "yorikiri." Experts provide insights and explore their iconic yorikiri moments.

programme.title: JAPAN FROM ABOVE: UP CLOSE / Co-production between NHK, Gedeon Programmes, ZDF Arte, and Voyage
programme.desc: In this episode, we meet a wasabi farmer in Azumino, Nagano Prefecture.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: Inner Conflict of the Human Soul
programme.desc: We visit the Yoshiwara district, Edo's most prominent pleasure quarters. Among the lavish spenders, courtesans and apprentices, small humanoid creatures scurry about -- what could they be up to? *"Good and Evil Influences in the Yoshiwara" (c.1800) by Eishosai Choki

programme.title: Japan in Focus
programme.desc: Kintsugi mends broken pottery with gold. An artist is restoring earthenware damaged by the Noto earthquake, helping residents put the pieces of their lives back together, too.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Eating together and making conversation, snack time connects people. For those living away from home, hometown tastes bring back nostalgia in just one bite. Anybody of any age is happy when sharing snacks together. In this episode, it's snack time all over Japan.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: Immunotherapy: New Hope for Uterine Cancer
programme.desc: Immunotherapy is offering a new approach to uterine cancer. Genetic testing can help predict how effective it may be. We also explore a new iPS cell-based treatment that rejuvenates immune cells.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: The San'in Kaigan Geopark Trail is a 230-kilometer-long course connecting the Sea of Japan coastline along Tottori, Hyogo, and Kyoto prefectures. It is a designated UNESCO Global Geopark. On the second half of his journey, Canadian actor Kyle Card explores the dynamic landscapes shaped by the separation of the Japanese archipelago from the Asian continent, as well as the culture and way of life that developed in the region.

programme.sub-title: Lending an Ear to the Tiny, Symbiotic World of Lichen

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: For hundreds of years, Japanese people have used name stamps, known as hanko, to sign their name. People use hanko in everyday situations, such as receiving a parcel, and in formal contexts, such as business transactions and marriage registrations. However, the move toward remote work, triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic, affected how these stamps were used. In a 5-minute digest, we discover the history of hanko and explore what a hanko-free future might look like.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Miyazaki: Flowers, Archery, and a Festival
programme.desc: A cat takes a nap among the fragrant flowers at a farm that grows sweet pea flowers. Another cat takes a nap at an archery range! We meet more local cats as residents celebrate a unique tradition.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Somewhere Street
programme.desc: Charleston, a historic East Coast port city founded in 1670, charms visitors with cobblestone streets, horse-drawn carriages, and rich history. It's loved by both international and US travelers.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Laugh Then Think: Japan's Offbeat Science
programme.desc: A desire to stop people from talking annoyingly led to thought-provoking inventions. Their creator, Kurihara Kazutaka, values the surprising perspectives generated by the debates they prompt.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Buddhist Statues: Figures of Belief and Beauty
programme.desc: Kyoto has about 2,700 temples where an array of benevolent, meek and ferocious Buddhist statues are worshipped. Sculptors breathe life into these objects of worship.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: The second in a special two-part EJW series. On Easy Japanese for Work, we've looked at many Japanese phrases that people use at work. Today, we'll review past phrases and learn Keego through some fun games. First, reviewing past key phrases. Past students and some of their coworkers join us to learn new phrases through a quiz. Today's students are from the Philippines and Vietnam. They must work together to come up with Japanese phrases. Next, at Keego Corporation, a fill-in-the-blank style quiz. How will our students do? Tune in to find out.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: "They're not trash cans, but resource bins," says Murakami Yuki. His love of making goes back to childhood. And at college he developed his own banana peel leather. Transforming garbage and scrap into useful materials – lampshades from coffee grounds or chairs from old receipts – his creations are unique, but they're also as biodegradable as possible, with minimal environmental impact. This sort of alchemy has earned praise and serious interest from industries facing issues surrounding waste.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Protecting Life and Hope Inside a Pediatric ICU
programme.desc: Inside Japan's largest pediatric ICU, critically ill children fight for survival while families face life-or-death decisions. This is a six-month record of hope, struggle, and ethical dilemmas.

programme.title: CYCLE AROUND JAPAN Highlights
programme.desc: Aomori Prefecture is beautiful, but its northern climate can be harsh. Our cyclist enjoys the warmest of welcomes in communities that historically had to cooperate closely in everything in order to survive.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Curly proposes to have a relay race during the upcoming class fun day. Shelly opposes the idea, but the relay race is decided on by majority vote. Educational theme: Making the best of school life and group activities.

programme.title: u&i
programme.sub-title: Episode 10: It's All Right to Be Boyish or Girlish
programme.desc: "i" plays baseball during recess. A boyish thing to do. But he actually likes making dolls. One day, he drops a doll in front of a girl, "u." "i" is worried that "u" will tell everybody about his hobby.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: Climate Change in Asia ep. 4: Saving Vietnam's Fields from Rising Water Levels
programme.desc: Water levels all over the world are rising, with regions at low elevation in particular danger. Vietnam's rice fields have been subjected to floods, endangering production of precious food supplies.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Nara Prefecture / Tsukamoto Yoshiharu (Architect) Long ago, people in Nara preserved ice by building an icehouse on a mountain ridge, showing how architecture can make use of natural characteristics.

programme.desc: *First broadcast on January 5, 2026 Hagi, a World Heritage site often described as an "open-air museum," is lined with merchant and samurai houses and retains much of its 17th-century townscape. Soak in the atmosphere, in time-lapse.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: The most common winning technique in sumo is when a rikishi forces their opponent out of the ring using "yorikiri." Experts provide insights and explore their iconic yorikiri moments.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: Immunotherapy: New Hope for Uterine Cancer
programme.desc: Immunotherapy is offering a new approach to uterine cancer. Genetic testing can help predict how effective it may be. We also explore a new iPS cell-based treatment that rejuvenates immune cells.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Train Cruise
programme.desc: We journey through the snowy landscapes of northern Fukui Prefecture in central Japan on the Echizen Railway. The local trains, which are a lifeline for residents, operate over a total distance of 53 kilometers and provide access to many sightseeing locations. Visit the 770-year-old Eiheiji and practice zazen meditation, sip locally brewed sake and dine on Echizen crab, as we train cruise through the natural winter wonderland of the old Echizen Province on the Sea of Japan.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Japanese paper, known as washi, is attractively textured and extremely durable. In Japan, it's used in everything from sliding doors to banknotes. Paper first arrived from China around the 7th century and spread alongside Buddhism. Recently, crafts featuring washi have been getting attention outside Japan, and new paper production methods―including using vegetable scraps―have been popping up. In a 5-minute digest, we explore washi's role in modern society and examine how it represents Japanese aesthetics.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.desc: This castle, 200 km north of Tokyo, was a battleground in Japan's last civil war in the mid-19th C. Modern warfare did not bring it down. We look at the secrets to the its strengths and its lords.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: This episode focuses on gekijo, or "theater." Japanese theaters have characteristic features that have produced many idiomatic expressions.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: In Saidaiji Eyo, a matsuri in Okayama Prefecture, thousands of near-naked men endure icy water and the winter cold as they are purified at the temple. This is part of one of Japan's most prominent "naked" festivals. Usually, the men scramble to grab one of two sacred wooden items called shingi, but the event was hit hard by COVID-19. Gradually, the normal rites are being reintroduced, and this time the public can view the climax. They enjoy performances of dancing and taiko drumming, as well as a firework display.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Spiritual Explorers
programme.desc: For 800 years, the Ogasawara family has taught Japanese etiquette through daily actions. We learn how this cultivates self-awareness and understanding of others.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.sub-title: KUMANO: Gateway to the Land of the Dead
programme.desc: Shugendo, a unique spiritual tradition, dates back 1,300 years. Through beautiful time-lapse footage, we show its practitioners and Kumano's sacred forests, long associated with death and rebirth.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: Explore how Japan uses artificial satellites and surface observation to quickly assess flood and earthquake damage, supporting disaster preparedness.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Nara Prefecture / Tsukamoto Yoshiharu (Architect) Long ago, people in Nara preserved ice by building an icehouse on a mountain ridge, showing how architecture can make use of natural characteristics.

programme.sub-title: Bright Young Minds on the Path to Nuclear Abolition
programme.desc: Some 500 Japanese high school students have called for nuclear-arms abolition as peace ambassadors over the past 25 years. We meet some of these young people striving for peace.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: For hundreds of years, Japanese people have used name stamps, known as hanko, to sign their name. People use hanko in everyday situations, such as receiving a parcel, and in formal contexts, such as business transactions and marriage registrations. However, the move toward remote work, triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic, affected how these stamps were used. In a 5-minute digest, we discover the history of hanko and explore what a hanko-free future might look like.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Miyazaki: Flowers, Archery, and a Festival
programme.desc: A cat takes a nap among the fragrant flowers at a farm that grows sweet pea flowers. Another cat takes a nap at an archery range! We meet more local cats as residents celebrate a unique tradition.

programme.title: CYCLE AROUND JAPAN Highlights
programme.desc: Aomori Prefecture is beautiful, but its northern climate can be harsh. Our cyclist enjoys the warmest of welcomes in communities that historically had to cooperate closely in everything in order to survive.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Curly proposes to have a relay race during the upcoming class fun day. Shelly opposes the idea, but the relay race is decided on by majority vote. Educational theme: Making the best of school life and group activities.

programme.title: u&i
programme.sub-title: Episode 10: It's All Right to Be Boyish or Girlish
programme.desc: "i" plays baseball during recess. A boyish thing to do. But he actually likes making dolls. One day, he drops a doll in front of a girl, "u." "i" is worried that "u" will tell everybody about his hobby.

programme.desc: Charleston, a historic East Coast port city founded in 1670, charms visitors with cobblestone streets, horse-drawn carriages, and rich history. It's loved by both international and US travelers.

programme.title: Laugh Then Think: Japan's Offbeat Science
programme.desc: A desire to stop people from talking annoyingly led to thought-provoking inventions. Their creator, Kurihara Kazutaka, values the surprising perspectives generated by the debates they prompt.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Buddhist Statues: Figures of Belief and Beauty
programme.desc: Kyoto has about 2,700 temples where an array of benevolent, meek and ferocious Buddhist statues are worshipped. Sculptors breathe life into these objects of worship.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: The second in a special two-part EJW series. On Easy Japanese for Work, we've looked at many Japanese phrases that people use at work. Today, we'll review past phrases and learn Keego through some fun games. First, reviewing past key phrases. Past students and some of their coworkers join us to learn new phrases through a quiz. Today's students are from the Philippines and Vietnam. They must work together to come up with Japanese phrases. Next, at Keego Corporation, a fill-in-the-blank style quiz. How will our students do? Tune in to find out.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: "They're not trash cans, but resource bins," says Murakami Yuki. His love of making goes back to childhood. And at college he developed his own banana peel leather. Transforming garbage and scrap into useful materials – lampshades from coffee grounds or chairs from old receipts – his creations are unique, but they're also as biodegradable as possible, with minimal environmental impact. This sort of alchemy has earned praise and serious interest from industries facing issues surrounding waste.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: For hundreds of years, Japanese people have used name stamps, known as hanko, to sign their name. People use hanko in everyday situations, such as receiving a parcel, and in formal contexts, such as business transactions and marriage registrations. However, the move toward remote work, triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic, affected how these stamps were used. In a 5-minute digest, we discover the history of hanko and explore what a hanko-free future might look like.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.sub-title: Miyazaki: Flowers, Archery, and a Festival
programme.desc: A cat takes a nap among the fragrant flowers at a farm that grows sweet pea flowers. Another cat takes a nap at an archery range! We meet more local cats as residents celebrate a unique tradition.

programme.title: Laugh Then Think: Japan's Offbeat Science
programme.desc: A desire to stop people from talking annoyingly led to thought-provoking inventions. Their creator, Kurihara Kazutaka, values the surprising perspectives generated by the debates they prompt.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Buddhist Statues: Figures of Belief and Beauty
programme.desc: Kyoto has about 2,700 temples where an array of benevolent, meek and ferocious Buddhist statues are worshipped. Sculptors breathe life into these objects of worship.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.desc: The second in a special two-part EJW series. On Easy Japanese for Work, we've looked at many Japanese phrases that people use at work. Today, we'll review past phrases and learn Keego through some fun games. First, reviewing past key phrases. Past students and some of their coworkers join us to learn new phrases through a quiz. Today's students are from the Philippines and Vietnam. They must work together to come up with Japanese phrases. Next, at Keego Corporation, a fill-in-the-blank style quiz. How will our students do? Tune in to find out.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: "They're not trash cans, but resource bins," says Murakami Yuki. His love of making goes back to childhood. And at college he developed his own banana peel leather. Transforming garbage and scrap into useful materials – lampshades from coffee grounds or chairs from old receipts – his creations are unique, but they're also as biodegradable as possible, with minimal environmental impact. This sort of alchemy has earned praise and serious interest from industries facing issues surrounding waste.

programme.title: Protecting Life and Hope Inside a Pediatric ICU

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: The San'in Kaigan Geopark Trail is a 230-kilometer-long course connecting the Sea of Japan coastline along Tottori, Hyogo, and Kyoto prefectures. It is a designated UNESCO Global Geopark. On the second half of his journey, Canadian actor Kyle Card explores the dynamic landscapes shaped by the separation of the Japanese archipelago from the Asian continent, as well as the culture and way of life that developed in the region.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: A group of men use ladles to throw water over the buildings they pass at Hibuse Matsuri, the Fire Prevention Festival in Minamisoma, Fukushima Prefecture. Temperatures are often below freezing, and bonfires help to keep everyone warm. The event conveys a prayer for the safety of residents and buildings in the coming year. It originated around 1,200 years ago, when bandits set fire to a local shrine. Legend has it that a herd of deer brought waterlogged bamboo grass to put out the flames.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.desc: Join us as we learn about life at the Otowasan Kannonji Temple through 24 terms from the solar calendar. On the winter date of Shokan, the nuns pick herbs in the temple's garden and make seasonal rice porridge. Then, we follow them on Daikan as they prepare kan-koji fermented rice and pickled napa cabbage. They also make a variety of winter dishes using dried vegetables.

programme.desc: Cases of Online Sexual Abuse and Exploitation of Children (OSAEC) are on the rise. We visit a Filipino NGO that protects victims, and helps them to recover.

programme.title: One in Every Japanese
programme.desc: 1 in 36 people in Japan are foreign residents. As its population declines, we look at Japanese society in a new era of foreign workers, through an IT startup where 90% of staff are foreigners.

programme.title: Japan in Focus
programme.sub-title: Ama Divers Restoring the Earthquake-Hit Seabed
programme.desc: In 2024, natural disasters devastated the fishing grounds of the ama (free divers) in Wajima, Noto. We follow their efforts to survey the seabed and revive their tradition.

programme.title: Japan's Top Inventions
programme.desc: Discover the stories behind renowned Japanese products alongside our reporter. This time: eggshell field chalk.

programme.sub-title: Uesugi Yozan: All for His People

programme.title: Train Cruise
programme.desc: We journey through the snowy landscapes of northern Fukui Prefecture in central Japan on the Echizen Railway. The local trains, which are a lifeline for residents, operate over a total distance of 53 kilometers and provide access to many sightseeing locations. Visit the 770-year-old Eiheiji and practice zazen meditation, sip locally brewed sake and dine on Echizen crab, as we train cruise through the natural winter wonderland of the old Echizen Province on the Sea of Japan.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: Japanese paper, known as washi, is attractively textured and extremely durable. In Japan, it's used in everything from sliding doors to banknotes. Paper first arrived from China around the 7th century and spread alongside Buddhism. Recently, crafts featuring washi have been getting attention outside Japan, and new paper production methods―including using vegetable scraps―have been popping up. In a 5-minute digest, we explore washi's role in modern society and examine how it represents Japanese aesthetics.

programme.title: Design × Stories

programme.title: Let's Enjoy MATH with Barky the Dog
programme.sub-title: Can You Make a Measure? ―Units of Length―
programme.desc: Numbler hides the measuring stick at a shoe shop so that a customer's foot cannot be measured. Barky realizes that the measurement can be made by counting how many 1-centimeter items are needed, and the customer's foot is measured successfully.

programme.title: TAKE TECH
programme.desc: Scissors allow us to cut all kinds of shapes, such as circles and squares, freely and precisely. This episode examines the simple but remarkable technology that makes this possible.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Time and Tide
programme.desc: This castle, 200 km north of Tokyo, was a battleground in Japan's last civil war in the mid-19th C. Modern warfare did not bring it down. We look at the secrets to the its strengths and its lords.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: This episode focuses on gekijo, or "theater." Japanese theaters have characteristic features that have produced many idiomatic expressions.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: In Saidaiji Eyo, a matsuri in Okayama Prefecture, thousands of near-naked men endure icy water and the winter cold as they are purified at the temple. This is part of one of Japan's most prominent "naked" festivals. Usually, the men scramble to grab one of two sacred wooden items called shingi, but the event was hit hard by COVID-19. Gradually, the normal rites are being reintroduced, and this time the public can view the climax. They enjoy performances of dancing and taiko drumming, as well as a firework display.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Spiritual Explorers
programme.desc: For 800 years, the Ogasawara family has taught Japanese etiquette through daily actions. We learn how this cultivates self-awareness and understanding of others.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.sub-title: KUMANO: Gateway to the Land of the Dead
programme.desc: Shugendo, a unique spiritual tradition, dates back 1,300 years. Through beautiful time-lapse footage, we show its practitioners and Kumano's sacred forests, long associated with death and rebirth.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: Explore how Japan uses artificial satellites and surface observation to quickly assess flood and earthquake damage, supporting disaster preparedness.

programme.title: DESIGN MUSEUM JAPAN
programme.desc: Nara Prefecture / Tsukamoto Yoshiharu (Architect) Long ago, people in Nara preserved ice by building an icehouse on a mountain ridge, showing how architecture can make use of natural characteristics.

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.sub-title: Attractive Yet Poisonous — Spotfin Lionfish, Philippines
programme.desc: The beautiful spotfin lionfish is also known as the "Lady of the Sea". Its flashy red and white stripes and long spines extending from the body make it instantly recognizable. But don't let the graceful appearance fool you. These fish are in fact extremely poisonous. The long fins contain venom that protects them against enemies. Their hunting style is also unique. They use their fins like feet to sneak up on their prey and swallow it whole with unbelievable speed. Shot in the waters of the Philippines, this episode reveals the amazingly deceptive nature of these graceful beauties.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.desc: Iwate Prefecture is home to many historic sites which were made to represent Buddhist paradise. Chuson-ji Temple in Hiraizumi, a World Heritage Site, is home to the golden Konjikido hall which offers a prayer for peace. The garden in Motsu-ji Temple was made as a depiction of paradise and has been also registered as a World Heritage Site. Catch a glimpse of eternity through time-lapse photography.
